questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following are storage symptoms of BPH?
questions.explanation:
Urgency, enuresis and frequency are storage symptoms. ˜ower urinary tract symptoms (˜UTS) can be classified as: Storage 
Voiding HesitancyPoor flowIntermitt 
ent streamDribblingSensatio 
n of poor bladder emptyingE 
pisodes of near retention ‘requency(earliest 
symptom 
in BPH)NocturiaUrgencyUrg 
e incontinenceNocturnal inco 
ntinence (enuresis) 948 
Sold by @itachibot Storage symptoms are seen in conditions where the bladder is irritated. Voiding symptoms are 
common in conditions causing bladder outlet obstruction. In benign prostatic hyperplasia, both 
storage and voiding symptoms are present.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 60-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and dysuria. On per-rectal examination, his 
prostate was tender and boggy. His PSA level was 7.4 ng/dl. What is the next best step in the 
management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bacterial prostatitis and should be managed by 
antibiotics. A rigorous and prolonged treatment for 2-6 weeks with an antibiotic that penetrates the prostate 
wall is indicated (trimethoprim, ciprofloxacin or aminoglycoside). Incomplete infection 
eradication lead to recurrent attacks and chronic prostatitis. Acute bacterial prostatitis is usually caused by an ascending urinary tract infection (UTI) or reflux 
of infected urine into prostatic ducts. The most common organism is Escherichia coli. An 
associated increase in levels of PSA(>4ng/ml) may be present due to prostate inflammation. Catheterization and prostatic massage are contraindicated in patients with suspected acute 
prostatitis, as they increase the chance for bacteremia and sepsis. Instead, suprapubic tap should 
be performed to alleviate retention. Chronic bacterial prostatitis is the sequela of inadequately treated acute prostatitis. Diagnosis includes: • Three-glass urine test - If the first glass with the initial urine sample is clear, but the second and 
third samples contain prostatic threads and leukocytes, it indicates the presence of prostatitis. • Digital rectal examination - Prostate may be normal, boggy, or tender. • Prostatic fluid examination - post-prostatic massage fluid shows pus cells and bacteria.

questions.question: Question 3: Which is the most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis?
questions.explanation:
The most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP) is Escherichia coli. It is commonly caused by an ascending urethral infection or reflux of infected urine into prostatic 
ducts. Sexually transmissible infections and other urinary pathogens, such as Staphylococcus 
aureus and Streptococcus faecalis may also be responsible. The patient presents with fever, perineal pain, chills and rigor, and dysuria. Per rectal 
examination will reveal a tender, boggy prostate. Care should be taken to avoid aggressive 
palpation or prostatic massage as it can lead to bacterial dissemination and sepsis. Urine examination and culture should be done. Urine examination reveals threads in urine. Management: Patients with systemic signs of infection should be admitted for IV antibiotics, hydration, and 
monitoring of laboratory parameters. Patients who have no signs of systemic infection, who can tolerate oral intake, and who have no 
urinary retention can be treated with oral antibiotics. Antibiotics are given for 2-6 weeks to ensure 949 
Sold by @itachibot the eradication of the infection as antibiotics don't penetrate the prostate capsule easily. ‘or outpatient therapy: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg oral every 12 hours or levofloxacin 500 mg OD or 
trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole double-strength tablet oral every 12 hours can be used. ‘or hospitalized patients: Intravenous ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin with or without an 
aminoglycoside (gentamicin or tobramycin) or intravenous beta-lactam with or without an 
aminoglycoside. Gram-positive infections are treated with cephalosporins (cephalexin, cefazolin) 
or dicloxacillin and vancomycin.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of following compounds form endogenous prostatic calculi?
questions.explanation:
Endogenous calculi are most commonly composed of calcium phosphate. Exogenous calculi are urinary calculi that are arrested in the prostatic urethra. They are relatively 
rare. Corpora amylacea are benign histological findings in prostate glands. Prostatic calculi are thought 
to develop from the calcification of corpora amylacea.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following is false regarding the medical management of benign prostatic 
hyperplasia?

options.a: 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors take at least 6 months to act.
options.d: 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors act best when the gland is small.

questions.explanation:
5-alpha-reductase inhibitors act best when the prostate is large(>50g). The pathogenesis of BPH has a static and dynamic component responsible for the lower urinary 
tract symptoms. Conversion of testosterone to DHT is responsible for prostatic stromal 
hypertrophy which is the static component of BPH. The contraction of smooth muscles in the 
prostate is considered the dynamic component of BPH. 950 
Sold by @itachibot Alpha-blockers

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following findings is not an indication to perform prostatectomy in patients with 
benign prostatic hyperplasia?
questions.explanation:
Increased frequency alone is not an indication for prostatectomy. Increasing difficulty in micturition, with considerable frequency during both day and night, delay 
in starting, and a poor stream are the usual symptoms for which surgery is advised. Other indications include the following: • Acute retention • Chronic retention and renal impairment • Residual urine of  200 m˜ • Raised blood urea • Hydroureter or hydronephrosis • Complications of bladder outflow obstruction • Stone • Infection • Diverticuli • Hemorrhage - Venous bleeding from a ruptured vein overlying the prostate

questions.question:
Question 7: Identify the approach for surgery of the prostate as shown in the image: 942 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows the transvesical approach, also known as ‘reyer approach. In this approach, the bladder is opened and the prostate is enucleated by putting a finger into the 
urethra, pushing forward towards the pubes to separate the lateral lobes, and then working the 
finger between the adenoma and the false capsule. Among the other approaches, TURP is most commonly performed. 951 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: As a first-year surgery resident, you have scrubbed in to assist a urologist on a TURP 
procedure. Up to what distal anatomical landmark do you expect him to resect?
questions.explanation:
Verumontanum is used as the distal-most border of the resection in transurethral resection of the 
prostate (TURP). This prevents damage to the external urethral sphincter which is located just 
distal to the verumontanum. Damage to the external urethral sphincter leads to urinary incontinence. The bladder neck is the proximal limit of resection.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient in your ward is scheduled for monopolar-TURP. Which of the given fluids should be 
used for irrigation during the procedure?
questions.explanation:
The best irrigating fluid for M-TURP is 1.5% isotonic glycine. 952 
Sold by @itachibot M-TURP removes tissue with a wire loop that has an electrical current flowing in one direction 
(monopolar). The surgical site is irrigated with a non-conducting non-ionic fluid as the use of an 
ionic solution leads to dissipation of the cutting current and poor cutting efficacy. Thus, normal 
saline and N/5 saline cannot be used. The use of distilled water in TURP leads to the water-intoxication syndrome. Bipolar transurethral resection of the prostate (B-TURP) uses a specialized resecting loop that 
incorporates both the active and the return portions of the circuit on the same electrode and an 
ionic irrigating solution such as normal saline can be used safely.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 70-year-old patient with benign prostatic hypertrophy underwent TURP. An hour later, he 
was found to have an altered sensorium and had several bouts of vomiting. What is the most 
probable cause?
questions.explanation:
The most probable cause for the above-mentioned symptoms is water intoxication also known as 
transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) syndrome. Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral urethral resection can lead to : • Hyponatremia, which may manifest as confusion, nausea, and vomiting • Congestive cardiac failure • Hemolysis It is managed by fluid restriction. The use of isotonic glycine for irrigation during resection reduces the incidence of water 
intoxication.

questions.question:
Question 11: A man presents with a history of minimal ejaculation at sexual climax and passing cloudy 
urine after. He is a known diabetic and underwent TURP 6 months ago. What is the 
mechanism leading to this complication?

options.a: Injury to the external urethral sphincter
options.b: Disruption of the autonomic nerve supply to the corpora of the penis
options.c: Over use of coagulating diathermy during the procedure

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario above suggests the patient has retrograde ejaculation. The most likely 
mechanism of its development is disruption of the bladder neck. Retrograde ejaculation is the most common complication of transurethral resection of the 
prostate (TURP). Option A: Injury to the external urethral sphincter causes incontinence following TURP. Option B: Disruption of the autonomic nerve supply to the corpora of the penis causes impotence. Option C: Overuse of coagulating diathermy following TURP causes bladder neck contracture. Other complications of TURP include: • Transurethral resection of prostate (TUR) syndrome • Primary and secondary hemorrhage • Perforation of the bladder or the prostatic capsule • Sepsis • Urethral stricture 953 
Sold by @itachibot Note:Transurethral microwave thermotherapy (TUMT), Transurethral needle ablation (TUNA), 
and laser vaporization are less invasive methods used for the treatment of BPH. They have a 
decreased incidence of ejaculatory dysfunction and hemorrhage.

questions.question:

options.c: Rectal mucosa mobile over the prostate

questions.question:
Question 13: A 6–- year-old patient presents with difficulty in initiating micturition. A DRE reveals an 
enlarged nodular prostate with adherent rectal mucosa. PSA was found to be 25 ng/ml and a 
biopsy result was suggestive of adenocarcinoma. Which of the following statements is false 944 
Sold by @itachibot regarding his condition ?

options.a: PSA is a not specific marker for the condition.
options.b: Gleason score correlates with the pathological stage
options.c: It is associated with decreased % free PSA
options.d: It arises from the transitional zone of the gland.

questions.explanation:
Prostatic carcinoma, as indicated in the clinical scenario, arises from the peripheral zone of the 
gland. Anatomically, the prostate is divided into three zones. • The peripheral zone lies posteriorly and has an abundance of prostatic glands. • The central zone lies posterior to the urethral lumen and above the seminal vesicles as they 
course through the prostate. • The transitional zone is periurethral. Benign prostatic hyperplasia arises from the transitional zone. 954 
Sold by @itachibot Gleason grading may be used after biopsy to evaluate the stage of histopathological specimen. 
Gleason scores range from 6 to 10 where 6 is low risk for prostate cancer while 10 is high risk. PSA (prostatic specific antigen) is a glycoprotein peptidase that facilitates the liquefaction of 
semen. It is useful for screening and for monitoring response to therapy but is neither specific nor 
sensitive to the condition as it can be elevated due to old age and benign conditions such as 
prostatitis and BPH. Slightly elevated total PSA (between 4.0 and 10.0 ng/m˜) and low free PSA (<25%) is suspicious 
for prostate cancer.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 63-year-old patient comes to the urology OPD with hesitancy, incomplete voiding, and 
pelvic pain. On a digital rectal examination, an irregularly enlarged prostate with a nodular 
surface is felt. The rectal mucosa does not move freely over it. A biopsy using an automated 
gun is planned. How many biopsy cores should be obtained?
questions.explanation:
Ideally, 12 systematic biopsy cores are obtained in patients with suspected prostatic cancer. A 12-core systematic biopsy that incorporates apical and far-lateral cores in template distribution 
allows maximum cancer detection. It also avoids detection of insignificant prostate cancers and 
the need of a repeat biopsy.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 77-year-old man was evaluated for a nodule found on his prostate. His PSA levels were 15 
ng/dl and a transrectal biopsy indicated a malignancy. Which of the following statements is 
false regarding its spread?

options.a: ˜ocal spread can occur to the seminal vesicles.
options.b: Direct involvement of rectum is common.
options.c: Obturator nodes are most commonly involved.
options.d: Spread by bloodstream usually occurs to the bones.

questions.explanation:
Palpable nodules over the prostate with raised PSA are highly suggestive of carcinoma. direct 
involvement of the rectum is rare but it may become stenosed by the tumor infiltrating around it. Option A: ˜ocal invasion occurs upwards, first involving seminal vesicles, bladder neck, and 
trigone; this is followed by distal invasion to the external sphincter. Obstruction of one or both 
ureters can occur resulting in anuria. Option C: ˜ymph nodes involved are obturator lymph nodes, external iliac nodes, and 
occasionally retroperitoneal, mediastinal, and supraclavicular lymph nodes. Option D: Spread by the bloodstream occurs mostly to the bones; the bones involved most 
frequently in carcinoma of the prostate are the pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 75-year-old man provisionally diagnosed with BPH underwent a TURP procedure. 
Histopathological exam of the resected tissue revealed a tumor involving less than 5% of the 
specimen. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
A tumor discovered incidentally on TURP present in <5% of resected tissue is staged as T1a. ‘or 
older men, conservative treatment is done for stage T1a prostatic carcinoma. Radical surgical treatment might be considered in younger (<70 years) men with the same stage 
of the disease. 956

questions.question: Question 18: Orchidectomy is used as treatment for which of the following stages of prostate cancer?
questions.explanation:
Orchidectomy is performed to carry out androgen ablation in the treatment of locally 
advanced disease in the elderly. It is also done to manage metastatic disease. Bilateral orchidectomy, whether total or subcapsular, will eliminate the major source of 
testosterone production. ˜HRH analogs such as goserelin and buserelin along with 
anti-androgens such as flutamide is used to perform medical androgen ablation. Management of Prostatic Car 
cinoma Stage of cancer 
Age > 70 or Gleason score=6 
Age < 70 or Gleason score >6 Early prostate cancer: T1,T2A 
Active surveillance 
Radical prostatectomy Brachytherapy + Androgen d 
eprivation therapy Brachytherapy + Radical pros 
tatectomy ˜ocally advanced prostate ca

questions.question:
Question 19: A 77-year-old man presented with worsening hip and back pain. The X-ray revealed the given 
lesions The patient had undergone an orchidectomy three years ago to manage his prostatic 
carcinoma. However, recent serial estimations of PSA have shown an increasing trend. What 
is the treatment of choice for his condition? 946 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Blastic lesions on X-Ray after surgical castration (therapeutic orchidectomy) in patients with 
prostatic carcinoma is suggestive of hormone-resistant bone metastasis. The treatment of choice 
for hormone-resistant bone metastasis is radiopharmaceutical therapy with radium-223. Radium-223 is a radioactive isotope that emits low levels of alpha-particle radiation. The 
alpha-particle radiation causes double-strand breaks in DNA, which kills cells. Radium-223 is a 
“calcium mimetic” that accumulates preferentially in areas of bone undergoing increased turnover, 
such as areas of bone metastases. 958 
Sold by @itachibot Management of Prostatic Car

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following vaccines is used in the treatment of prostate cancer?
questions.explanation:
Sipuleucel-T (Provenge) is an autologous prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP)-loaded dendritic cell 
vaccine. It is approved for patients with hormone-resistant, metastatic prostate cancer with minimal or no 
cancer-related symptoms. Other immunotherapies in prostate cancer include: • GVAX allogeneic recombinant whole-cell vaccine • Immune checkpoint inhibitors such as PD-1/PD-˜1 inhibitor • CT˜A-4 inhibitor Option A: Talimogene laherparepvec (T-VEC) has demonstrated therapeutic activity in melanoma. Option B: Bacillus Calmette–Guérin is used for bladder carcinoma. Option D: Algenpantucel-˜ is used as immunotherapy in pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is used in laser enucleation of the prostate?

options.a: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture
options.b: Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
options.d: Micturating cystourethrography with prostratic urethra stricture

questions.explanation:
Ho-YAG laser is the most common laser used in enucleation of the prostate. The procedure is 
known as Holmium laser enucleation of the prostate (Ho˜EP). ˜aser reduce the duration of the procedure and the risk of harmorrhage. šTPA green light laser is the best laser that can be used. It causes vaporisation of prostatic tissue. 
As it is hemostatic in nature, it can be safely used in patients on anticoagulants. 959 
Sold by @itachibot Urethra and Penis
